item.description:
After a steady diet of long drives to the Berkshires and New Hampshire this week's hike will be a bit closer to home. As a man of the blues I can't think of a better destination than the Great Blue Hills. The GBH's 7000 acre reservation is located south of Boston in the towns of Milton, Canton, Randolph, Braintree, Dedham and Quincy (map). With more than 125 miles of roads and trails in this reservation there's a meetup group devoted to this one area.

I'm proposing a loop trail starting from the Trailside Museum on Route 138. (http://www.massaudubon.org/Nature_Connection/Sanctuaries/Blue_Hills/index.php)

At about 10 miles and 2,100 elevation gain (nothing to shake a stick at) we'll start by taking the red dot trail from the Trailside Museum to the summit of Great Blue Hill. Then continue East along the South Skyline trail to the summit of Houghton's Hill. Leave the Skyline trail, heading South (right) to Houghton's Pond. Follow the shore of the pond (either the North or the South shore, the latter is slightly longer) to the orange blazed Massachuseuck Trail. Follow it, first North and then East, along the sides of Tucker and Buck Hills. On the East slope of Buck Hill (just above Rt 28) you will meet the Skyline Trail, head back West (left) over the summits of Buck and Tucker Hills to Hillside Street. Then go over Hancock, Hemmenway and Wolcott Hills to Great Blue Hill and back to the start.

Having never been in the park before a safe return depends on everyone's navigational support, a compass and a wee bit of luck of the Irish. With temp's in the high 50's on Sat it looks like a perfect day for hiking. The usual advisories apply in terms of hydration (recommend 2-3 liters of water,) plenty of snacks, thick sole and sturdy boots (no snow boots,) and lots of wicking clothes (no cotton.) With this distance and elevation one should not take this hike lightly.

I'm including the standard list of equipment here, but use your best judgement given the location and temperature forecast for Saturday. I'll forward weather advisories or other helpful tips as required prior to the hike. Check with others for car pooling. 

EQUIPMENT CHECKLIST

Cold Weather/Fall Essentials (required):
• Synthetic Quick-drying Pants
• Synthetic Quick-drying L/S Shirt
• Sturdy Hiking Boots/shoes (preferably waterproof)
• Synthetic/Wool Socks
• Insulated/Fleece Jacket
• Light/Mid-weight Insulating Layers (undershirt/underpants)
• Extra pair of Socks
• Hat/Gloves
• Rain/Soft Shell Jacket/Pants
• Water (2-3L)
• Headlamp/Flashlight
• Map/Compass/Whistle
• Lunch
• Snack/Energy Food (extra food)
• MICROspikes, STABLicers, ect... (a must when there's snow or ice on the trail)

RI Outdoors has begun to plan some winter hikes. If you're interested in leading hikes or have suggestions for hikes and/or skiing trips please contact John the meetup Organizer or an Assistant Organizer.

Let's kick back and enjoy this hike!!
item.name: Sing the Great Blue Hills Hike
